questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with generalized nocturnal pruritis for 1 week. A dermoscopy image of his hand is shown below. The patient is started on a drug that inhibits the sodium channels of the parasite. Identify the likely drug.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of generalized nocturnal pruritus and an image showing burrows in the interdigital spaces suggest scabies infection. The indicated drug that acts by inhibiting the sodium channels is 5% permethrin cream.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused by Sarcoptes scabiei and transmitted by close personal contact. Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women. This pattern of distribution is known as the circle of Hebra. In adults, the face is often spared.

The image below shows the lesion distribution along the circle of Hebra:


A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the treatment of choice for scabies. 

All family members, even if asymptomatic, must be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection. Oral ivermectin is preferred in cases of Norwegian scabies. All clothes and bedding used by the infected person must be washed at high temperatures and kept in a bag for 72 hours to prevent transmission to close contacts.

A 25-year-old male patient presented with painless, fleshy, exophytic lesions on the surface of the penis. Evaluation reveals the causative organism to be low-risk strains of HPV. What is the first-line management used for this condition?

HPV - human papillomavirus
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painless exophytic lesions on the genitalia caused by low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) strains is suggestive of anogenital warts. Imiquimod is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition.

Anogenital warts are caused by low-risk strains of HPV, commonly HPV-6 and HPV-11. The lesions present as soft, pink, and fleshy warts. These growths may be pedunculated or verrucous and coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths known as condyloma acuminata.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by HPV DNA PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

The first-line drugs used in the treatment are topical podophyllin and imiquimod. Second-line management includes cryotherapy, local application of fluorouracil, or 80–90% trichloroacetic acid. Cryotherapy is a relatively safer management that can be used in pregnant women for treating warts.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a V-shaped hypopigmented patch in the forehead that is pathognomonic of piebaldism. Impaired migration of melanocytes is responsible for this condition.

Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the KIT gene. Clinically, it presents an isolated V-shaped hypopigmented patch on the forehead at birth called a white forelock. 

The treatment is conservative and includes sun protection at the site of the hypomelanotic patch. Epidermal or skin grafting can be tried for cosmetic purposes.

Other options:

Option B: Deficiency in the tyrosinase enzyme is seen in oculocutaneous tyrosinemia. It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye.

Option C: Defective phagolysosome fusion is seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the loss of function mutation of the LYST gene. It presents with significant pyogenic infections, oculocutaneous albinism, and neurological abnormalities. 

Option D: Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes is seen in vitiligo. It is an acquired condition characterized by patchy depigmentation.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with intensely itchy lesions on the extensor aspect of both elbows and knees.  A skin biopsy was done, and a direct immunofluorescence image revealed focal granular deposits as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of intensely itchy lesions on the extensor aspect of both elbows and knees with direct immunofluorescence (DIF) showing focal granular deposits along the basement membrane is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis, also known as Duhring’s disease is an auto-immune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla. This condition is closely associated with Celiac disease (Gluten-sensitive enteropathy). 

The clinical manifestations include grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, and scalp with symmetrical distribution and are associated with intense pruritus. 

The characteristic histopathology finding is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils, which is shown in the image below: 


A gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment, but it takes months to years to show clinical improvement. Hence, dapsone is used for short-term management in these patients.

Other Options:

Option D: Systemic lupus erythematosus, on DIF shows a speckled appearance of the basement membrane (shown below).

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient who is a known case of HIV presents with an erythematous rash with superficial flaking as shown in the image. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic HIV patient with erythematous patches with superficial flaking (scaling) on the nasolabial fold and cheeks is suggestive of seborrheic dermatitis infection.

Seborrhoeic dermatitis (SD) is caused by lipophilic yeasts from the Malassezia species. These yeasts are found in parts of the body with a high density of sebaceous glands, such as the scalp, face, central chest, and anogenital areas.

An image showing seborrhoeic dermatitis of the scalp is given below:


Seborrhoeic dermatitis is one of the most common HIV-associated dermatoses and occurs early in the course of HIV disease. Treatment of adult seborrheic dermatitis is with topical antifungals (ketoconazole), topical glucocorticoids, and, in some cases, topical calcineurin inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy skin often seen along the flexural areas of the body, such as the elbows and knees.

Option B: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction with itchy, erythematous papules and papulovesicles that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. 

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis is an autoimmune disorder of the skin usually associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). It typically presents with multiple pruritic erythematous macules and papules that typically appear over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp.

questions.text: A patient presents to the dermatology clinic with tender nodular lesions over the shin as shown in the image below. Histopathology shows histiocytes with neutrophilic infiltration without vasculitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing nodular lesions on the shin and histopathology showing neutrophilic infiltration of the dermis without vasculitis is suggestive of erythema nodosum.

Erythema nodosum (EN) is a cutaneous reactive septal panniculitis with no vasculitis. It is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction. It is most commonly idiopathic but can be associated with conditions like:

  • Infections: Streptococci (most common), tuberculosis 
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): Crohn's disease more than ulcerative colitis 
  • Sarcoidosis 

It presents with symmetrical, erythematous, and tender subcutaneous nodules or plaques typically distributed over the anterior aspect of the limbs. Over a few days, these lesions become purplish before finally turning brown. Ulceration never occurs. The clinical course is self-limiting. Treatment of underlying causes is the mainstay of management. It reverses following drug withdrawal and usually resolves within 2–4 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Sweet's syndrome presents as an acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis with evidence of leukocytoclastic vasculitis (debris of neutrophils found on blood vessels). It is characterized by non-itchy, sometimes tender, erythematous plaques and papules. 

Option C: Behcet's syndrome is also a neutrophilic dermatosis but presents as recurrent oral and genital aphthous ulcers with an erythematous halo.

Option D: Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), or type 2 lepra reaction, is an immune complex-mediated syndrome (type 3 hypersensitivity) affecting the skin, nerves, and other organs. It is mainly seen in the multibacillary form of leprosy.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with a rash for the past 5 days as shown below. There is a history of loose stools and loss of hair for 1 month. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a baby with diarrhea and alopecia and the image showing erythematous plaques in the anogenital area are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene on chromosome 8q. This encodes for the ZIP4 transporter in enterocytes, leading to zinc deficiency.

Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive, with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a ‘U-shaped’ or ‘horseshoe-shaped’ appearance. Risk factors include weaning from breast milk, premature infants, anorexia nervosa, alcoholism, vegetarianism, and inadequately supplemented total parenteral nutrition. 

Affected infants require lifelong zinc supplementation at a dose of 3 mg/kg/day.


Other options:

Option A: Candida dermatitis usually occurs secondary to diaper dermatitis. It is a type of contact dermatitis and is not associated with diarrhea or alopecia.

Option C: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that occurs due to type 1 hypersensitivity reaction triggered by exogenous agents. It is often associated with allergic rhinitis and bronchial asthma. The rash is seen on the flexural areas of the body, such as the elbows and knees.

Option D: Seborrhoeic dermatitis (SD) is a common, relapsing dermatitis characterized by erythematous patches with superficial scaling. It affects areas with a high density of sebaceous glands.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with purple, pruritic plaques on the volar aspect of the wrist.  He says that he first noticed it around 4 months back and is worried about the new lesions that are appearing at the places of injury. A skin biopsy done to confirm the diagnosis shows the following histology. What is the structure marked?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lichen planus. The structure marked in the histopathological image is of Civatte bodies.

Civatte bodies / colloid bodies are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consisting largely of keratin intermediate filaments and immunoglobulins. 

Lichen planus is characterized by idiopathic inflammation of the skin and mucosal tissues. It has a chronic course with frequent relapses. It manifests as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques, which are the 6Ps of lichen planus. It also exhibits Wickham striae (thin white lacy lines on the lesion) and the Koebner phenomenon (new lesions at sites of skin trauma).

Histopathology of the lichen planus typically shows interface dermatitis, flattening or saw toothing of rete ridges, Max Joseph’s space at the dermo-epidermal junction, and Civatte or colloid bodies.

The following image shows loss of rete ridges and interface dermatitis:


The following image shows characteristic lesions of lichen planus:


Other options:

Option A: Schaumann bodies are laminated concretions of calcium and proteins seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis.

Option B: Asteroid bodies are also seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are stellate inclusions within giant cells.

Option C: Donovan bodies are characteristic of granuloma inguinale (also called donovanosis). These are the macrophages encapsulating Klebsiella granulomatis coccobacilli.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic complaining of gradual thinning of hair on the crown of his head. On examination, a diffuse reduction in hair density on the crown area of his scalp, with some areas showing complete baldness. The hair follicles appear miniaturized. There are no signs of inflammation or scarring. What is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and examination findings are suggestive of androgenetic alopecia, also known as male pattern baldness. Oral finasteride is one of the mainstay treatments for androgenetic alopecia in men. 

Androgenetic alopecia is a patterned hair loss that causes thinning of the vertex and an M-shaped receding hairline. High levels of circulating androgens, mainly 5-dihydrotestosterone (DHT), stimulate hair loss in certain sites by a process called miniaturization. 

Finasteride inhibits 5α‐reductase, a hormone responsible for converting testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). By reducing DHT levels, finasteride helps to slow down hair loss and promote regrowth.

Other Options:

Option A: Topical corticosteroids are not typically used as a first-line treatment for androgenetic alopecia. They may be used in cases where there is an associated inflammatory component.

Option C: Oral cyproterone acetate is used to treat female-pattern baldness. It blocks the androgen receptors, acts as a potent progestin, and has an anti-gonadotrophic effect. 

Option D: Oral spironolactone is mainly used for the treatment of female-pattern baldness. It is an aldosterone antagonist. It competitively blocks androgen receptors.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with painful ulcers on his penis as shown below. Examination reveals tender unilateral lymphadenopathy progressing to buboes. He gives a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the recommended first-line treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Azithromycin 1 g on day one, followed by 500 mg daily for 6 weeks
Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 3 days
Doxycycline 100 mg on day one, followed by 100 mg twice daily for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with painful ulcers along with tender lymphadenopathy progressing to buboes is suggestive of chancroid. The first-line drug is azithromycin, 1 g orally as a single dose.

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. The primary lesion begins as a painful papule that undergoes central necrosis to form painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges. It is associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which later progresses to form suppurating buboes and sinuses. Auto-inoculation can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones, forming so-called kissing ulcers.

First-line management is azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose or ceftriaxone 250mg IM in a single dose.

Other options:

Option B: Azithromycin 1 g on day one, followed by 500 mg daily for more than 3 weeks, is the first line of drug management for granuloma inguinale or donovanosis. It presents with a painless, beefy red ulcer with no lymphadenopathy and is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 3 days is second-line management for chancroid. Alternatively, erythromycin can also be used as a second-line management.

Option D: Doxycycline 100 mg orally on day one, followed by 100 mg twice daily for at least 3 weeks, is an alternate drug regimen for donovanosis.

questions.text: A teenage football player presents with painful erosions on the axilla. On skin biopsy, the histopathological findings of suprabasal split with a dilapidated brick wall appearance of acantholytic cells are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of painful erosions on the flexors, i.e., axilla, and biopsy findings of a suprabasal split with a dilapidated brick wall appearance of acantholytic cells is suggestive of Hailey-Hailey disease.

Hailey Hailey disease is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the ATP2C1 gene ​​encoding the calcium ATPase channel. Due to this, desmosomal function in the suprabasal and basal layers is disturbed, leading to acantholysis. 

It presents as flaccid blisters, particularly in the intertriginous areas. Since there is heat and friction in such areas, the blisters rupture forming macerated plaques. On histology, acantholysis is seen throughout the epidermis, giving rise to the ‘dilapidated brick wall’ appearance.  


Since it is not an immunological disorder, the immunofluorescence is negative.

Other options:

Option A: In Darier disease, there is a suprabasal split with dyskeratotic keratinocytes. It is shown in the image below:


Option B: In Pemphigus vulgaris, there is a suprabasal split, but the acantholytic cells are not present across the entire thickness of the epidermis.

Option C: In Bullous pemphigoid, there is no acantholysis.

2. Rupoid psoriasis  b. Lake of pus

questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B: 1 - c, 2 - d, 3 - a, 4 - b

Type of psoriasis  Features
1. Inverse psoriasis  c. No scales 
2. Rupoid psoriasis  d. Conical scales 
3. Guttate psoriasis  a. Rain drop-like lesions 
4. Pustular psoriasis  b. Lakes of pus 


Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces. 

Lesions can be described as:

  • Red, scaly, and have well-defined demarcation from the normal skin.
  • Encircled by a clear peripheral zone, which is called the Woronoff ring.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

Plaque psoriasis (most common): Sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.)

Guttate psoriasis: small, scattered erythematous papules with a characteristic appearance like dew or raindrops. It usually occurs weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis in children.

Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities

Pustular psoriasis: macroscopic pustules within lesions, which are described as lakes of pus. 

Scalp psoriasis: well-demarcated plaques on the retro auricular areas and posterior upper neck.

Flexural/inverse psoriasis: thin plaques affecting intertriginous folds, with minimal or no scaling.

Rupoid psoriasis: limpet-like conical scales are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs most commonly causes drug-induced pemphigus?
questions.solution:
The most common drug that causes drug-induced pemphigus lesions is pencillamine due to the presence of a thiol group (S-S).

Pemphigus is an intra-epidermal blistering disorder. These blisters are formed due to a separation within the skin, which then collects fluid resulting in bullae. Some medications can cause pemphigus-like lesions, particularly those with a thiol group (S-S). The most common drug that causes this is penicillamine, followed by ACE inhibitors. Other drugs include:

  • Antibiotics - Penicillins, cephalosporins, rifampicin
  • Aspirin
  • Piroxicam
  • Glibenclamide
  • Phenobarbital

Drug-induced pemphigus typically occurs after one year of taking the medication and is more common in individuals with other associated autoimmune conditions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, with a previous history of tuberculosis, presents with the following lesion over his nose. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this skin lesion?

choices.text: Tubercle bacilli are abundantly seen in histology of all lesions
BCG vaccination is one of the causes for this disease
Squamous cell carcinomas may develop as a complication of this lesion

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing a reddish-brown ulcer with elevated borders and central atrophy of the nose in a patient with a history of tuberculosis is suggestive of lupus vulgaris. Tubercle bacilli are usually absent in the lesions, i.e., lupus vulgaris is a paucibacillary condition.

Lupus vulgaris is one of the most prevalent forms of cutaneous tuberculosis. It is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary form of tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals, with high immunity. It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis. It may even occur as a result of BCG vaccination or at the sites of a tattoo or scrofuloderma.

The spread may be hematogenous, lymphatic, or due to exogenous inoculation leading to peripheral extension. Scarring, contractures, and tissue destruction are the major complications seen in lupus vulgaris. Long-standing lupus vulgaris may lead to squamous cell carcinoma.

A positive PCR can confirm the diagnosis. Histology will show tubercles with minimal central caseation, surrounded by lymphocytes, epithelioid histiocytes, and multinucleate giant cells in the superficial dermis. Diascopy may reveal apple-jelly nodules.

The natural course of the disease is progressive. Standard multidrug antitubercular therapy should be given.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female patient presents with difficulty in activities such as climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, and brushing her hair in the past few months. She was recently diagnosed with lung cancer. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. Which of the following findings will be present on muscle biopsy?

choices.text: Perimysial inflammation and atrophy with CD4+ T-cells

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of muscle weakness and a positive shawl sign in the upper chest in a lung cancer patient is suggestive of dermatomyositis. A muscle biopsy of this condition shows perimysial inflammation and atrophy with CD4+ T-cell infiltrates.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle. It presents with symmetric, proximal muscle weakness associated with skin manifestations such as:

  • Heliotrope rash: Erythema of eyelids with periorbital edema, as shown in the image below:

 

  • Gottron’s papules: Violaceous, flat papules on the skin overlying the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints, as shown in the image below. These are the characteristic lesions of dermatomyositis.

 

  • V-sign: Erythematous macules over anterior chest
  • Shawl sign: Erythematous macules over posterior neck and upper back

DM is associated with interstitial lung diseases and internal malignancies, most commonly adenocarcinomas. Adult-onset DM has a stronger association with malignancies.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Histopathology will show perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates, perivascular infiltrates, and perifascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

First-line management is done with high-dose glucocorticoids.

  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presents with lesions on her palms and trunk. On examination, the lesions show central erythema surrounded by a pale zone and an outer ring of erythema. She was diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease 1 week back and has been taking ceftriaxone for the same. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describing target lesions that are seen after the intake of ceftriaxone (a cephalosporin) is suggestive of erythema multiforme.

Erythema Multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs. It presents clinically with macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, along with the classic acral iris or target lesions. The lesions are distributed on the distal extremities, palms or trunk, and oral and genital mucous membranes.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones namely, the central area of dusky erythema or purpura, the middle paler zone of edema, and the outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge. The lesions appear in successive crops for a few days and fade in 1–2 weeks. Atypical lesions will have only 2 zones.

The common triggers of erythema multiforme are herpes simplex infection, mycoplasma infection, drug reactions by sulfonamides, cotrimoxazole, penicillins, etc., bacterial infections, fungal infections, vaccinations, and malignancies.

Other options:

Option C: Fixed drug eruptions/reactions are a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. They are usually solitary or few and recur at the same location. However new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug. Paracetamol/NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

questions.text: A lady presents with bluish discoloration in the right eye and the surrounding periorbital skin since birth. She says that it has been increasing in size over the years. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a lady presenting with a bluish discoloration in the right eye and the surrounding periorbital skin since birth, which has been increasing in size over the years, is suggestive of nevus of Ota.

Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis distributed along with the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Most of the lesions occur at birth or during the first year of life. The lesion increases in size and number over the years, and the second peak of onset can also occur during puberty. These lesions do not disappear with time. Females are more commonly affected.

Management includes Q-switched lasers and cosmetic camouflage.

Complications include meningeal melanocytoma of the brain and malignant melanoma involving the meninges, choroid, iris, or orbit. In some rare cases, cutaneous melanoma can also develop.

Other options: 

Option A: Mongolian spots are slate blue areas in the lumbosacral region that spontaneously regress before puberty.

Option B: Becker's naevus is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis. It is often hairy. The onset is around adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens, especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest

Option C: Naevus of Ito is unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular distribution.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of bloody anal discharge, rectal pain, and tenesmus. On examination, there is ulcerative proctitis. The patient reveals that he had unprotected anal intercourse 3 weeks ago. This was followed by painful lesions in the genital area that healed without scarring. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic proctitis with a history of anal intercourse and lesions in the genital area that healed without scarring is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venerum.

Lymphogranuloma venerum is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The organism spreads from the site of the initial lesion to the regional lymph nodes, causing lymphangitis. There are three stages of the disease: 

Primary: The incubation period is 3–30 days. The genital lesions may be painful or painless. The patient usually presents with symptoms of hemorrhagic proctitis. The condition is common among homosexuals. 

Secondary: It may take days to weeks for the disease to manifest. It is characterized by tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal or femoral lymphadenopathy (groove sign). The lymph nodes coalesce to form painful buboes which rupture and form fistulae and sinus tracts. 

Tertiary: Genito-anorectal syndrome is seen occurring years after an untreated primary infection. There is lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This results in genital lymphoedema and inflammation, which cause ulceration and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, resulting in esthiomene in women and elephantiasis in men.

Option B: HSV-2 infection presents with macular or papular vesicles that progress to vesicles and pustules lasting for up to 3 weeks. It is associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

Option C: The incubation period for chancroid is 3–10 days. The patient presents with painful deep ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy. The primary lesion begins as a painful papule that undergoes central necrosis to form painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges. Kissing ulcers due to autoinoculation may also be present.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis presents with a painless papule that forms a beefy red ulcer with no lymphadenopathy. The incubation period is 8–80 days.

questions.text: A 56-year-old AIDS patient presented with the following lesions on his legs. Examination reveals similar lesions over the buccal mucosa. Biopsy reveals spindle cell vascular proliferation and promontory sign. What is the likely diagnosis?

Kaposi's sarcoma is a soft tissue tumor due to endothelial proliferation that occurs in immunosuppressed individuals and is caused by human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8).

A definitive diagnosis requires a biopsy. The biopsy will reveal horizontally arranged vessels dissecting through collagen bundles around the adnexa and surrounding pre-existing vessels (promontory sign).

It is treated by local excision, liquid nitrogen, or injection of vincristine. It generally has a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A sexually active man diagnosed with syphilis presented with a recurrence of the primary lesion at its original site. On examination, there is painless lymphadenopathy and Treponema is isolated from the site of the lesion.  Which stage of syphilis is he currently in?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing recurrence of syphilis at the primary site and presenting with a painless lymphadenopathy isolating Treponema from the site is suggestive of early relapsing syphilis. This is also known as "chancre redux."

Chancre redux is a highly infectious recurrence of the primary sore at its original site. This may be associated with painless lymphadenopathy.

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is usually acquired through sexual contact. However, congenital syphilis is acquired as a transplacental infection. Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and RPR. Specific treponemal antibody tests, like TPHA and FTA-ABS, are further required. Microscopically, Trepenoma pallidum is identified with a characteristic wave-like appearance on darkfield microscopy.
 
Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. If the patient has a history of drug allergies, it is advisable to keep the patient under observation for 15 to 20 minutes after injection. Treating recent sexual contacts is recommended. 

Note: Pseudochancre redux is a gummatous lesion seen in tertiary syphilis that is not infectious. It occurs at the site of a previously healed chancre, and the adjacent lymph nodes are not enlarged.

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection

questions.text: A patient with a slow-growing ulcerated lesion was diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: They mostly occur on the head and neck

questions.solution:
Since basal cell carcinoma does not have a premalignant stage, option B is incorrect.

Basal cell carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumor with locally invasive characteristics affecting the pilosebaceous skin. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation exposure, human papillomavirus infection, immunosuppression, photosensitizing drugs, occupational factors, and arsenic exposure. 

On histopathological examination, they can be the multifocal superficial type that extends over the skin surface or the nodular type that grows into the dermis. They have hyperchromatic nuclei in a mucinous matrix and are surrounded by fibroblasts and lymphocytes. They demonstrate peripheral palisading (option A).

The below image shows the histological features of BCC:

Gross morphology: The most common type of BCC is nodular BCC. They are pearly, have a rolled border, and may be ulcerated (option C). Ulcerated BCCs are called rodent ulcers. Nodular BCCs are most commonly present on the head and neck (option D). 

The below image shows a nodular BCC with ulceration over the supraorbital area. 

BCCs can be managed medically with imiquimod, 5 fluorouracil, and intralesional interferon alpha-2b. Surgical methods involve excision with predetermined margins, curettage and cautery, and Moh's micrographic surgery. 

Note: Squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) have premalignant stages. SCC may arise from actinic keratosis, cutaneous horn, arsenical keratosis, post-ionizing radiation keratosis, disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis, and Bowen disease. However, these lesions are considered to have uncertain malignant potential and share histological characteristics.

questions.text: A farmer came to the outpatient clinic with a cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury. A histopathological image of the lesion is given. Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a cauliflower-shaped mass developing after a minor injury is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. The histopathological image showing round, dark brown bodies is sclerotic bodies.

Chromoblastomycosis is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. The fungus enters the skin by traumatic implantation. Patients present with warty cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genus Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents.

Diagnosis is by demonstration of sclerotic bodies in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae. 

The condition can be managed with amphotericin B or thiabendazole. For small lesions, surgical excision is the therapy of choice.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of brittle hair and hair loss. Hair under microscopy is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading to complaints of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.
  • White piedra: It is characterized by soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, and facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Management involves shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

Other options:

Option B: Tinea nigra is a localized fungal infection of the stratum corneum, especially affecting the palms. It produces brownish/blackish macular lesions. It is caused by Exophiala werneckii. 

Option C: Pili torti seen in Menke's syndrome or Tricholipodystrophy or Steely hair disease which is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Option D: Trichorrhexis nodosa is associated with node formation and fractures. The classic appearance, shown in the image below, is known as thrust paintbrush appearance as if two paintbrushes are rubbing against each other. It is associated with trauma to the hair shaft and arginosuccinic aciduria.

questions.text: A patient presents with hyperpigmented macules on the toe-web spaces. Wood’s lamp examination image is shown below. What is the most commonly associated organism?
questions.solution:
The image of Wood's lamp examination shows coral-red fluorescence, which is suggestive of erythrasma. It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, which is a gram-positive bacilli.

Erythrasma is a superficial skin infection that generally affects the axillae, groins, toe webs, inter-gluteal, and submammary regions. It is common in diabetics and immunodeficient patients with obesity, sweating, and poor hygiene.

Lesions may be asymptomatic or show mild discomfort and itching. These are usually irregular with sharp margins. They may start as smooth, red patches and then become brown.

Coral‐red fluorescence with Wood’s light is due to coproporphyrin III. The fluorescence may even persist after the eradication of the disease. 

Treatment of erythrasma is by using topical imidazoles (clotrimazole) or topical antibiotics (fusidic acid) for two weeks. For more extensive lesions, oral erythromycin can be administered. In cases of relapse, long-term topical povidone-iodine application with drying agents can be used. Photodynamic therapy can also be attempted.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the OPD with the following lesions shown in the image. It is present on the trunk and thighs but not on the palms and soles. Which of the following signs is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing reddish brown maculopapular lesions all over the body except palms and soles is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa. Darier’s sign is positive in this condition.

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. It is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia in neonates.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in asymmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other options:

Option A: Headlight sign is the facial eczema sparing the periorbital, perinasal, and perioral areas. It is a feature of atopic dermatitis.

Option B: Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma and is caused due to the piloerection of the muscle.

Option C: Hertoghe's sign or Queen Anne's sign is defined as loss of lateral one-third of eyebrows (superciliary madarosis). It is seen in various conditions such as hypothyroidism, lepromatous leprosy, atopic dermatitis, trichotillomania, and alopecia areata.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought by his mother to the OPD with complaints of lesions as shown below following sun exposure. The boy didn't have any lesions at birth and these changes started to appear at an early age following sun exposure. What is the condition that the boy is likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of skin lesions only after birth and severe sunburn reactions showing erythematous macules in the face following sun exposure is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum.

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in nucleotide excision repair leading to hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

Initially, there is diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckles, which later progress to poikiloderma. It presents as skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4–5 years, they present with multiple malignancies, including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

XP also leads to ocular manifestations such as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. The accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. 

Management includes avoidance of ultraviolet radiation exposure through the application of sunscreens, UV protective glasses, etc. Vitamin D deficiency is common and should be supplemented. It is a fatal disease and these measures tend to improve life quality and prolong life expectancy.

Other options: 

Option A: Lupus can present with rashes and ulcers on epithelial surfaces but it does not have lesions due to sun exposure.

Option B: Neurofibromatosis type 1 is autosomal dominant disorder characterised by cafe au lait spots, neurofibromas and pigmented iris hamartomas. It does not have sensitivity to UV radiation

Option D: Acne rosacea is a disorder that appears mainly in people within 30 to 50 years of age. The lesions are mainly present on the convexities of the face.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented to the emergency room with a progressive painful and pruritic rash covering his entire body as shown in the image below. DNA analysis from tissue samples for T-cell receptors (TCR) showed clonal rearrangements of the T-cell receptor genes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with the image showing fine, scaly, erythematous plaques and DNA analysis showing clonal arrangements of T cell receptor genes, is suggestive of mycosis fungoides.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ helper T cells), which usually stays confined to the skin. It usually involves the limb/girdle, breast, and especially the buttock area. It can disseminate into the blood, which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Analysis of the TCR gene for clonal rearrangements is now a standard approach for Mycosis fungoides, which has diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic implications. It is a marker of a monoclonal T-cell population. 

Histological hallmarks include:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells: cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded or hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses: tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism: invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in Mycosis fungoides:

Other options: 

Option A: Follicular mucinosis is a condition characterized by the deposition of mucin in the sebaceous glands. It presents as papules and well-demarcated lesions. However, it is not characterized by clonal arrangements of T cells. 

Option B: Bowen's disease is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia. However, it does not have clonal arrangements of T cells. 

Option C: Psoriasis is a condition that presents as salmon-coloured lesions with a silvery plaque and presents on the extensor surfaces. This patient's lesions are all over his body, making it unlikely.

questions.text: Which of the following layers of skin contain lamellar bodies that are responsible for the discharge of lipids into the intercellular space and barrier function?
questions.solution:
Odland bodies (lamellar bodies) are seen in the uppermost cells of stratum spinosum (layer C) and throughout stratum granulosum (layer B). These are mainly responsible for the discharge of lipids into the intercellular space and barrier function. The lipids discharged by the Odland bodies help in intercellular cohesion within the stratum corneum.

From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are marked in the below image:

Stratum corneum: it is the outermost layer of the epidermis with dead, flattened cells filled with keratin.

Stratum lucidum: it is seen only in palmoplantar skin and contains nucleated cells known as ‘transitional’ cells.

Stratum granulosum: it has tight junctions, intracellular keratohyalin (filaggrin) granules, and lamellar (Odland) bodies.

Stratum spinosum: it consists of enlarged keratinocytes with spinous processes known as acanthocytes. This layer is rich in desmosomes and also Langerhans cells.

Stratum basale: it is a continuous layer, usually only one cell thick, rich in K5/K14-keratin filaments. Melanocytes and Merkel cells are present here.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following phases of the hair cycle starting with the phase corresponding to hair growth:
  1. Catagen
  2. Anagen
  3. Telogen
  4. Kenogen
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of hair growth is Anagen, Catagen, Telogen, and Kenogen. 

The hair cycle is a repetitive sequence of growing and resting phases of hair follicles. Anagen is the active period of hair growth. The duration of this phase determines the final length of the hair.

Epithelial cell division declines and ceases at the end of the anagen phase and hair follicles enter into an involutiontary phase called catagen. The proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle is involuted by apoptosis during this phase.

The telogen phase is the time gap between the completion of follicular regression and the onset of the next anagen phase.

The shedding of club hair occurs through an active process termed exogen.

In the human scalp, kenogen indicates the interval in which the hair follicle remains empty after the telogen hair has been shed and before a new anagen hair emerges.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text:
Match the following nail changes in psoriasis with their corresponding images.
  1. Oil drop sign
  2. Nail pitting
  3. Ridging
  4. Onycholysis with subungual keratosis
questions.solution:
The correct option matching the nail changes in psoriasis with the corresponding images is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, and 4-B.

Any part of the nail unit may be affected. This includes the nail bed, nail matrix, and hyponychium.

Nail matrix disease presents with pits, ridges, and grooves in the nail plate. Pitting is the most frequent change seen in fingernails. 

Nail bed disease is seen as subungual ‘oil drops.’ It is highly specific for psoriasis. Other changes involving the nail bed include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: Capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking or pressure on the skin occurs in ________________.
questions.solution:
Capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking or pressure on the skin occurs in white dermographism.

Dermographism refers to an exaggerated flare and wheal response that occurs when skin is stroked or scratched. Dermographism is the most common form of chronic inducible urticaria or physical urticaria. Various forms of dermographism include:

  • Black dermographism: It is characterized by discoloration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object
  • White dermographism: This is due to capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking or pressure on the skin. It can occur normally but is particularly pronounced in atopic eczema
  • Simple dermographism: The triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin.
  • Cholinergic dermographism: It is seen in some patients with cholinergic urticaria. Here, the demographic response consists of an erythematous line studded with punctate wheals.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the dermatology OPD with multiple abrasions and erosions of his knees, elbows, ankles, and hands. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy performed showed linear deposits arranged in a 'u'-serrated pattern and a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa acquisita is made. The type of collagen involved in this condition is:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the direct immunofluorescence showing linear deposits arranged in a 'u'-serrated pattern is suggestive of epidermolysis bullosa acquisita. It is characterized by autoantibodies to type VII collagen (C7) structures, a major component of anchoring fibrils, which attach the epidermis to the dermis. 

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita is an acquired autoimmune disorder, presenting in adults between 44-54 years. It has a chronic, relapsing course. Two main clinical forms can be differentiated:

  • Classical mechano-bullous - Skin fragility, erosions, blisters, crusts, and scars on trauma‐prone areas like hands, knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes.
  • Inflammatory - Resembles other pemphigoid diseases such as bullous pemphigoid. Associated with inflammatory infiltrate in the dermis.

Linear IgG deposits in a u-serrated pattern on direct immunofluorescence microscopy are suggestive of epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA) and are considered a gold standard for diagnosis. The image given below shows the linear deposits with a 'u'-serrated pattern seen in epidermolysis bullosa.

Other options: 

Option A: Osteogenesis imperfecta is caused by a defect in type I collagen. It presents as a severe decrease in bone mass that makes bones brittle, associated with blue sclerae, dental abnormalities, progressive hearing loss, and positive family history.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with an itchy elevated lesion on her face as shown in the image. On dermoscopy, there is an atypical pigmented network. Which of the following will be the best indicator to assess the prognosis of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an asymmetrical pigmented lesion on the face with an irregular border suggestive of malignant melanoma. The best prognostic factor in primary melanoma is provided by the tumor thickness, the Breslow index.

Malignant melanomas are malignant tumors arising from melanocytes.

Breslow index is a measure of the distance between the overlying epidermal granular layer and the deepest level of invasion of the primary melanoma.

Other prognostic factors for primary melanoma:

  • Sentinel node status
  • Ulceration
  • Mitotic rate of cells
  • Age of the patient (negative for older age)
  • Sex of the patient (negative for males)
  • Site of the lesion(negative for head and neck)

Other options:

Options A and C: Age (young) and sex (female) respectively are favorable prognostic factors in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Lymphovascular invasion has a role to play in assessing the prognosis of primary melanoma. However, Breslow's index is the best prognostic factor.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby is brought with complaints of high fever for 3 days. Today, the fever subsided but the mother noticed a rash on the trunk as shown below. On oral examination, ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction are present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of fever and ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction (Nagayama spots) along with the image showing a rose-colored morbilliform rash on the trunk of an infant makes the likely diagnosis roseola infantum.

Roseola infantum is also called as sixth disease or exanthema subitum (exanthema=breaking out, subitum=sudden rash). It is caused by a human Herpesvirus (HHV) 6A, 6B, and 7.

Clinical features:

  • Prodrome of high-grade fever
  • Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down.
  • Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis
  • Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction

The image below shows a rash of roseola infantum:

This is a self-limiting disease and treatment is done as supportive care in the form of maintaining hydration and using antipyretics if the child has a fever.

The image below shows a neonate with papulo-nodular erythematous-bluish lesions of a blueberry muffin baby:

Option C:  Chickenpox presents with papules that very rapidly become tense, clear, unilocular vesicles. It is present more on the trunk and less in the extremities and different stages of the rash can be seen at one time.

The image below shows a rash in a severe case of chickenpox. Observe the maculopapular rash and multiple vesicular lesions in different stages. The white marks are due to the application of medicament ointments and creams.

Option D: A rash with a slapped cheek appearance is seen in erythema infectiosum. It is a sudden onset of diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks. questions.text: A 5-year-old child is referred to a dermatologist with a history of the development of multiple large bullae and crusting around the nose and mouth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describing large bullae and crusting of lesions in a young child is suggestive of a diagnosis of bullous impetigo.

Impetigo is a contagious superficial pyogenic infection of the skin. It is mainly caused by Staphylococcal infections and less commonly by Streptococcal infections. It is frequently seen in preschool and young age children. Poor hygiene, overcrowding, and existing skin diseases (especially scabies and eczema) predispose to a higher occurrence of impetigo.

The site is commonly involved in the skin around the nose and the mouth. It has two types.

  • Bullous impetigo presents as large bullae that progressively increase in size (1-2 cm in diameter) and do not rupture easily.
  • Non-bullous impetigo presents as thin-walled vesicles with an erythematous base.

The diagnosis is mainly clinical but skin scrapings from affected skin can be obtained for microbiological confirmation.

Bullous impetigo is treated with systemic antibiotics. In addition to that, the management of impetigo involves washing the skin, removing crusts, and applying topical antibiotics. 

The image below shows a picture of bullous impetigo with the presence of large bullae and crusting over ruptured lesions:

This is an image of an impetigo around the mouth showing the honey-colored crusts:

Other options:

Option A: Bullous pemphigoid presents mainly in elderly people. It starts with urticated and erythematous lesions, which may be pruritic. This is followed by the formation of tense blisters on normal or erythematous skin. Histopathology shows subepidermal splitting, and autoantibodies are seen against BP180 and BP230.

Option C: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with mucosal erosions, usually in the oral mucosa. These may precede cutaneous lesions or be the only manifestation. Cutaneous lesions are seen as flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid, mainly on the scalp, neck, face, and upper trunk. These may rupture and become painful erosions.

Option D: Herpes labialis presents as itching or burning followed by the formation of small closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base, usually around the mouth.

questions.text: The given image shows the progression from stage 1 to stage 3 of a dermatological disease in a female child. This disease is also associated with dental abnormalities, onychodystrophy, ocular, and neurological abnormalities. It is caused by mutations of the IKBKG gene. What is the inheritance pattern seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical images of stages 1 and 3 of the disease, along with dental abnormalities, onychodystrophy, ocular, and neurological abnormalities due to mutations in the IKBKG gene is suggestive of incontinentia pigmenti. The pattern of inheritance is an X-linked dominant inheritance.

Incontentia pigmenti manifests as a multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males. It presents in females with skin lesions, dental abnormalities, alopecia, onychodystrophy, ocular, and neurological findings. It is associated with defects in the IKBKG gene. The lesions can be described in 4 distinct stages, which are:

  • Stage 1 - Erythematous vesicular rash
  • Stage 2 - Verrucous lesions
  • Stage 3 - Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls 
  • Stage 4 - Atrophic linear streaks or patches 

The images below show stage 1 lesions and stage 3 lesions along the lines of Blaschko respectively.

The cutaneous lesions are seen along Blaschko's lines (image below), which are lines of normal developmental growth patterns in the skin.

Extracutaneous abnormalities include:

  • Dental abnormalities like delayed dentition, missing or malformed cone‐shaped teeth
  • Onychodystrophy 
  • Alopecia
  • Ophthalmological abnormalities with retinal neovascularization
  • Central nervous system (CNS) abnormalities like microcephaly, seizures, neurocognitive, and motor impairments.

Management:

No specific treatment is available. Symptomatic treatment includes standard management of blisters. Ophthalmological follow‐up is required for retinal neovascularization monitoring and treatment. Orthodontist for dental abnormalities, along with speech therapy if required. Pediatric neurologist for CNS abnormalities and seizures.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Which of the following color would you expect on Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pruritic lesions over the trunk and image showing sharply demarcated multiple hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches with fine scales is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor or tinea versicolor. On Wood's lamp examination, these lesions show pale yellow fluorescence. 

Wood's lamp is a source of ultraviolet rays. All visible rays from this source are excluded by Wood's filter. In fungal infections like pityriasis versicolor, it shows the pale yellow fluorescence as given below.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but it often spreads to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. 

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Relapse is very common. 

Other options:

Option A: Coral pink fluorescence is seen in erythrasma.

Option B: Red fluorescence is seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

Option D: Green fluorescence is seen in tinea capitis infections associated with Microspora species and favus.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with the following lesions. Her serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were found to be higher than normal. What is the likely systemic disease associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with cutaneous red-purple indurated plaques and nodules over the nose and cheeks and elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme levels is likely to have lupus pernio. The likely systemic disease associated with this condition is sarcoidosis. 

Cutaneous sarcoidosis presents as red‐brown or red violaceous nodules or plaques, generally multiple, and does not cause symptoms. Diascopy reveals the subtle brown‐yellow or ‘apple jelly’ color characteristic of granulomatous diseases but is usually more opaque than in lupus vulgaris. At diagnosis, at least 60% of patients have an increased serum angiotensin‐converting enzyme level.

Lupus pernio is the most distinctive manifestation of cutaneous sarcoidosis. It presents as infiltrated erythemato-violaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, a prominent telangiectatic component is characteristic. The clinical appearance is due to the presence of epithelioid cell granulomas in the dermis.

Lupus pernio is usually painless and, as it does not tend to ulcerate, is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris. In more than half of cases, it is associated with sarcoidosis of the upper respiratory tract, especially in patients with involvement of the nasal rims. It is also frequently associated with pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts, particularly affecting the terminal phalanges.

The image below shows the apple jelly appearance on diascopy:

Other options:
Option A: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option B: Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis. The lesions are usually plaques with soft, reddish-brown papules. The lesions gradually become elevated, infiltrated, and grow by slow peripheral extension to become gyrate or discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The following image depicts the lesions of lupus vulgaris.

Option C: Erysipelas presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges. It is caused due to streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes with complaints of patchy hair loss, as seen in the photograph below. Dermoscopy of the scalp skin was normal. On histology, numerous empty canals were seen. Clefts were noticed in the hair matrix and the follicular epithelium is separated from the connec­tive tissue sheath. Intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and image suggest that the most likely diagnosis is trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania is a psychiatric disorder characterized by com­pulsive hair pulling. There is increased tension before the hair-pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair-pulling. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.

Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.

Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages. Numerous empty canals, severely damaged follicles, and clefts in the hair matrix are also seen. The follicular epithelium separates from the connec­tive tissue sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. 

The image below shows alopecia areata:

Option B: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows Tinea capitis:

Option D: Traction alopecia is caused by hairstyles that impose a sus­tained pull on the hair roots. The pattern of the hair loss will reflect the dis­tribution of the traction.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to you during your rural posting as a part of a routine checkup camp to show the lesions as below. The red papular lesions do not cause him any discomfort and have been present for 6 months. His spot blood sugar is 300mg/dl. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given maculopapular lesions on the shins along with uncontrolled blood sugar point towards a diagnosis of diabetic dermopathy.

Diabetic dermopathy:

  • It presents as asymptomatic, oval, dull‐red papules 0.5–1 cm in diameter that evolve slowly on the shins, forearms, thighs, and over bony prominences, producing a superficial scale and, ultimately, atrophic brown scars.
  • Binkley's spots or diabetic shin spots is another name for diabetic dermopathy. The phrase diabetic dermopathy was coined by Binkley in 1965.
  • Pathologically, there is hyperpigmentation of the epidermal basal layer, deposition of haemosiderin and melanin in the dermis, and arteriolar basement membrane thickening.
  • Diabetic dermopathy is common and is a marker for complications of diabetes such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

Other Options:

Option A: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder that is seen in diabetic patients. The most likely etiology is microangiopathy. Most rashes are located on the legs, especially above the tibiae. The patches are initially brown and later may progress to yellow atrophic plaques.

Option C: Granuloma annulare is most commonly found in children and females <30 years. It manifests as groups of 1-2mm papules that range from skin-colored to violaceous, in an annular arrangement over distal extremities. There is no confirmed association with diabetes.

Below image shows granuloma annulare:

Option D: Furuncle/ boil is caused by Staphylococcus. It is painful and usually situated in the neck area. It is pustular and later becomes necrotic and forms a scar.

questions.text:
The given image illustrates a therapeutic modality for certain skin conditions. Which of the following diseases cannot be treated by this therapy?
  1. Psoriasis
  2. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  3. Vitiligo
  4. Dermatomyositis
  5. Dysplastic naevus syndrome
questions.solution:
The given image shows phototherapy being used as a treatment modality. It cannot be used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, and dysplastic naevus syndrome. On the contrary, they are absolute contraindications for phototherapy.

Phototherapy is a form of treatment where nonionizing radiations, commonly ultraviolet radiation are used on the skin. It can be in the form of 

1. UVB- Ultraviolet B rays are the rays that have wavelengths between 280 and 320 nm. If all these wavelengths are used it is called a full spectrum. If only 311–313 nm is used, then it is called narrow-band UVB. It has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties. The use of UVB does not require the wearing of any photoprotective gear. It can be used for thin plaque and macules, and in pregnancy, and in people with liver diseases.

2. UVA-Ultraviolet A are radiations that have wavelengths between 320 and 400 nm. It is usually used in combination with a psoralen photosensitizer, either orally or topically (PUVA). It acts by cross‐linking of DNA by psoralen photoadducts, inhibition of DNA replication, Langerhans cell depletion, immunosuppressive effects on T‐lymphocyte function and migration, and the restoration of Th17/ regulatory T-cell imbalance in psoriasis. It is used in lesions refractory to UVB, thick plaques, palmoplantar disease, nail disease, etc. 

3. Photopheresis involves the addition of psoralen to the patient’s white blood cells after they have been separated from whole blood ex vivo. The photoactivated white blood cells are then irradiated with UVA and reinfused back into the patient. It is used in the treatment of the erythrodermic stage of cutaneous T‐cell lymphoma, graft‐versus‐host‐disease, etc

Common diseases where phototherapy is used are:

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption
  • Lichen planus, etc

Absolute contraindications of phototherapy:

  • Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Genetic skin cancer syndromes (xeroderma pigmentosum, Gorlin syndrome)
  • Bloom syndrome, Cockayne syndrome

questions.text: A young woman had been to a beach for vacation. The next day, she developed the following skin lesions which were very itchy. On examination, the lesions are raised. There were no lesions on the face. She avoided sun exposure for the next 4-5 days and the lesions disappeared. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of raised itchy skin lesions that occur after sun exposure but spare the face and disappear after avoiding sun exposure is suggestive of polymorphic light eruptions. 

It is a recurrent, delayed‐type hypersensitivity (type IV) to sunlight (or artificial ultraviolet rays source) that resolves without scarring. Itchy eruptions appear hours after exposure to the sun. If the patient is exposed to the sun in mid-day, lesions might appear in the night or the following day. Sparing of the face and dorsal aspect of hands is usually seen. This is due to tolerance induced by repeated perennial ultraviolet radiation exposure. On avoiding sun exposure, the lesions disappear within days to weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Sunburn usually presents as painful erythema. It may occur in any sun-exposed areas like the face, hands, etc. It resolves in three to seven days. Scaling, desquamation, and tanning can be seen four to seven days after exposure.

Option B: Heat contact urticaria is one of the rarest forms of inducible urticaria. Localized warming of skin at temperatures from 38 to 44°C for 2–5 min induces wealing at the test site. It usually lasts for an hour.

Option C: In solar urticaria, weals develop within minutes of exposure to sunlight. On avoiding the sun, they disappear within 2 hours.

questions.text:
A girl presented with itching and oozing from a lesion on the ear after wearing nickel earrings. Identify the correct statements about the test used to confirm the diagnosis.
  1. Based on delayed hypersensitivity reaction
  2. Eczematous disorders unresponsive to treatment is an indication
  3. Testing should be delayed for 4 weeks following sunbathing
  4. Low-dose steroids hamper the positive response and are a contraindication for the test
  5. The optimum site for the test is the abdomen
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above is suggestive of allergic contact dermatitis to nickel. The test used to confirm the diagnosis is the patch test and statements 1,2 and 3 are the correct statements regarding it. 

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity (Statement 1) to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2, and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site- Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm. The abdomen and thigh are less suitable sites, that are very rarely used.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment (Statement 2)
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing (Statement 3), and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may result in false negatives in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg of prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected.
